desc: CDK6 encodes the cyclin-dependent kinase 6 which is one of the serine/threonine kinases that controls the checkpoint at G1-S phase. Upon receiving mitogenic signals, it forms a complex with cyclin-dependent kinase 4 (CDK4) and cyclin D, phosphorylates and inactivates retinoblastoma (RB), thus leading to the induction of a gene expression program regulated by the E2F family of transcription factors (PMID: 12432268). The negative regulator of CDK4/6, p16INK4a (encoded by cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 2A gene, CDKN2A), binds to the catalytic domains of the kinases and interferes with cyclin D and ATP binding (PMID: 9751050, 11124804). As CDK4 and CDK6 have partially overlapping and redundant physiological roles and they both regulates the cell cycle, alterations in CDK6 expression and activity may likely to promote tumorigenesis in a way similar to CDK4 (PMID: 15315761). For instances, CDK6 is shown to induce the expression of VEGF-A in lymphoid leukemia, thus it not only promotes cell proliferation but angiogeneisis as well (PMID: 23948297). CDK6 amplification has been observed in several cancer types, such as esophageal carcinoma, leukemia and lymphoma (PMID: 21593195, 22450065, 24423610, 9422538, 10879740, 16782810). However mutations in CDK6 are rarely detected in cancers (cBioportal, MSKCC, May. 2015) and there are very little functional data on their roles in tumorigenesis or therapeutics responses.

desc: CDK6 encodes an intracellular kinase involved in cell cycle progression. Amplification of CDK6 is found in a wide range of cancers.
